item.title: I have written a JVM in Rust
item.description: - Author has created a JVM in Rust for learning purposes, named rjvm, which is a toy JVM and not a serious implementation.

item.title: Study finds billions of nanoplastics released when microwaving containers
item.description: - Microwaving plastic baby food containers can release billions of nanoscopic particles and millions of microscopic ones, according to a study from the University of Nebraska–Lincoln.

item.title: Web Environment Integrity API Proposal
item.description: - The post discusses a proposal for a new API called Web Environment Integrity API.

item.title: Journalists should be skeptical of all sources including scientists
item.description: - A group of prominent scientists published a paper on the origin of COVID-19 that contradicted their true beliefs, sparking a scandal.

item.title: In the LLM space, "open source" is being used to mean "downloadable weights"
item.description: - The term "open source" is being used in the LLM (Large Language Model) space to refer to downloadable weights of AI models, rather than full access to the training code and dataset.

item.title: 'World of Warcraft' players trick AI-scraping website into publishing nonsense
item.description: - The World of Warcraft subreddit discovered that a gaming website was scraping their threads and using an AI to summarize them into articles.

item.title: Dementia risk linked to blood-protein imbalance in middle age
item.description: - Abnormal levels of certain proteins in middle age could be an early sign of Alzheimer's disease or similar conditions.

item.title: Llama: Add grammar-based sampling
item.description: - The post introduces a new feature called "grammar-based sampling" in the Llama software.

item.title: Show HN: Primo – a visual CMS with Svelte blocks, a code editor, & SSG
item.description: - Primo is a visual CMS that allows you to easily build pages and manage content using blocks.

item.title: Nanosecond timestamp collisions are common
item.description: - Nanosecond timestamp collisions are common on modern systems, occurring in approximately 5% of all samples when reading the clock on all 4 physical cores at the same time.
